I am very disappointed in this continued pro-Wright Brothers propaganda. The only thing they can be credited for having done first is inventing the "wing warping" method of controlling an aircraft and attaching a gas-powered engine to it. MUCH of the heavier-than-air flight engineering had been done previously by others, and they had many contemporaries that arguably may have flown first. Sam Langley, Gustave Whitehead, and even Otto Lilienthal (if you count gliding as heavier-than-air flight).

Sorry to be a total geek about this, but at 7:05 you say "design a Command Module to land on the moon and then take off again". The Lunar Module landed on the moon. The Command Module orbited it. (Just ask Micheal Collins, the guy you don't remember from Apollo 11.)
"wait for it" sounded like Barney Stinson
The safety bicycle was arguably 25 years old by 1903, but the bicycle is way older.

7:01 - The Command Module was never designed to land on the Moon.
That was the job of the Lunar Module. Strange that nearly 200 comments in, I have not seen anyone point out that glaring error.
But overall, nicely done.
Let's also take a minute to appreciate Charles Taylor, the master machinist, mechanic, and unsung hero to the Wright Brothers.

The further this series goes, the more respect I'm losing for Curiously. As an astronuclear historian, both the nuclear revolution and the aeronautical revolution have been covered even more pithily than my public school education. As much as I'd LOVE to recommend this channel to people, I've already spent more than a part-time job a week debunking the inaccuracies, glossings over, and general uselessness of this fluff.

Orbits above a specific point are geostationary orbits, not geosynchronous orbits. Geosynchronous orbits don’t have to be above the equator because they, by definition, only must orbit with the same period as Earth. To stay above a certain point, you must be above the equator and orbit with a period the same as Earth’s rotational period.

Love your content, but I'm disappointed how you just leaped over Robert Goddard straight to Von Braun. Von Braun himself said that most of his work is based on Goddard's patents, as he was the first person to build and test liquid-fuel rockets. I know you can't mention EVERY person in a field, but Goddard INVENTED the modern rocket as we know it. Just a small nod would have been enough.

Was expecting better from you Crash Course. You say that the Wright brothers were the first to fly an heavier-than-air aircraft but this is a lie! Otto Lilienthal was the first to do that in 1891 even if it was not motorized, it was only a glider. The Wright brothers were still not the first to fly a motorized aircraft as this title goes to Clément Ader in 1897 even if he could not perfectly control his aircraft. This is only now that the Wright brothers arrive. They are the first to fly a motorized heavier-than-air aircraft that they could control (maybe it is Gustave Whitehead in 1901 but we are not 100% sure so I will give you a pass on that). They however did not took off alone (the 1903 Wright flyer did not have wheels). It was propulsed by a sort of catapult and a system of rails. The first to do a motorized and controled flight in a self-propulsed heavier-than-air aircraft is Traian Vuia in 1906.
Hope you are not going to make that mistake again (not a big one) but this is what happens when you don't detail enough)
Continue what you are doing though I love it!
